I've just been down there actually

not only from his own party's on opf who

to demand the resignation of Robert

impeachment proceedings had just begun
only a few hours earlier and a
constitutional attempt to depose Robert
Mugabe as president and that could have
taken days some members of parliament
were saying that impeachment process
could have actually taken weeks or maybe
even months and some people were
beginning to worry that maybe Robert
Mugabe would never leave power
he's 93 years of age the oldest head of
state on the planet it's extraordinary
how long he has clung to power really as
a ruthless dictator somebody who has
presided over a government of brutal
political repression and economic chaos
inflation at one stage in this country
under his rule reached in 2008 79
billion percent it is a story of
extraordinary political repression and
economic mismanagement it is finally
over nobody knows quite what is going to
replace it to be absolutely honest the
favored candidate of the military is
Ernest Managua who has been a henchman
of Robert Mugabe and a lot a great
champion of freedom or democracy or
human rights he's the one that the army
wants to replace Mr Mugabe we're going
to have to wait to see what happens for
the moment though just seems of
uncontrolled joy in Harare and I have to
say as somebody who's been coming here
for the best part of 20 years
it is an emotional moment I covered some
of the brutal attacks 17 years ago on
white farms in Zimbabwe where farmers
were driven out of their properties and
sometimes murdered just one of the
instances of brutality under the Mugabe
regime it is over and no one knows quite
what will replace it but everything has
changed in Zimbabwe I don't think anyone
can doubt that now the genie is out of
the bottle democracy well it may not be
a country of democracy yet but the
people have tasted people power they've
come out onto the streets in their tens
of thousands they are still as I speak
literally running through unity square
down there you can't see too much of it
because there's so many trees there but
the Parliament is just beyond those
trees and that's where they've been
gathered that statement of resignation
that letter of resignation read out by
the Speaker of the Parliament just down
there behind those trees where those red
rubes are and the speaker read out the
letter and the news only just now a few
minutes later filtering out to the
people of Harare and the people of
Zimbabwe it is an incredible moment and
it is a moment of history in
post-colonial Africa this country that
has suffered so grievously for so many
years ninety percent unemployment at the
moment is just one statistic I can give
you to show how miserable life is at the
moment in Zimbabwe millions have sinned
barbarians have gone over the border to

to find some sort of employment that is
why there are scenes now of delirium
everyone is Tooting their halls if
they're in a car and if they're a

thus reach now towards the parliament's
which has been the focal point of this

persuaded Robert Mugabe to go because
he's been under pressure from the

for 37 years people who have criticized

beaten
they've been tortured and they've been
